Various Co-N-C catalysts including nanoparticles and single-atom sites were prepared using a low-temperature synthetic strategy by vacuum calcining with high exposure of the active sites and low energy consumption. When used in the formic acid (FA) dehydrogenation reaction, the obtained single-atom sites catalyst displayed high catalytic activity with a high H2 production rate of 27,361 mL·g−1·h−1. Moreover, the single-atom sites catalysts can still exhibit astonished catalytic performance in 88% FA (cheapest commercially available grade of FA) due to their super stability and special mechanism of reaction. From TEM, XRD, HAADF-STEM, XPS, and XANES characterization, the atomically dispersed active sites in the single-atom sites catalysts caused by strong metal-nitrogen coordination is believed to be the key to the success of this reaction. Moreover, the mechanism difference between nanoparticles and single-atom sites on aqueous formic acid dehydrogenation over coblat catalyst was illustrated. Graphical abstract The mechanism of SAC and NP catalyst were both discussed through contrast experiment and isotope effect experiment. Finally confirmed the reaction proceeds through the HCO2 − dehydrogenation path on NP catalyst and HCO2H dehydrogenation path on SAC. Image, graphical abstract Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen, the most abundant and simplest element in the universe, is rising due to technical advances in fuel cells. Furthermore hydrogen is also the potential successors to electrical energy storage, industrial chemicals and the internal combustion engine [1]. However the hydrogen storage problems have curtailed the development of hydrogen energy utilization [2]. In the existing methods, chemical hydrogen storage is increasingly attracting people's attention. Several concepts based on the use of chemical compounds, for example, formic acid (FA), methanol, sodium borohydride and ammonia borane etc., have been proposed for hydrogen storage and release [3]. FA has already been suggested for hydrogen storage since several decades ago [4–8]. Some unique features such as high stability, high hydrogen density (4.4 wt% and 53 g/L), liquid state at room temperature, environmental benignity, and non-toxicity, make FA a promising renewable hydrogen donor. The FA can be prepared via the reduction of CO2, and stored in the liquor state stably, which is able to release H2 through catalytic dehydrogenation [8]. Both the fixation and the evolution of hydrogen need to be supported by suitable catalysts. Recently, the hydrogen production from FA is attracting more and more attentions from researchers, for example Jiang, etc. [9–11]. On the basis of these published works, it has been made possible for FA to decompose highly selectively at low temperatures to produce hydrogen. However, basically all these FA dehydrogenation reactions are performed with heterogeneous catalysts containing noble-metal (Pd, Au etc.), which increase catalysts cost and limit the scale up of hydrogen storage with FA [12]. Li et al. reported a cobalt single atom catalyst (SAC) that is able to catalyze FA dehydrogenation with high catalytic activity (the H2 production rate is 23.6 LH2·gCo −1·h−1) [13]. The single Co(II)Nx sites were prepared by pyrolysis of ZnCo zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZnCo-ZIFs), which were proved to be the active sites in the new catalyst. At the same time, some methods are reported recently to prepare Co SAC catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) by adding zinc into the precursors [14–16]. The intentional addition of Zn2+ can replace a certain proportion of Co2+ sites and serve as ‘fence’ to expand the adjacent distances of Co atoms. The evaporation of Zn at high temperature (over 900 °C) can make the Co SAC catalysts with enhanced porosity. This method is simple and effective, promoting it to a hot spot in SAC catalysts research [17–19]. However, there are still problems with this method that the sample yield and N functional sites can be sacrificed due to the calcining at high temperature. Our research group has gained interests and experience in heterogeneous catalysts for hydrogen generation from FA since 2015 [20–24]. In our previous work, the synthesized PdAg@ZrO2/C catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity (turnover frequency of 9206 molH2·molPd −1·h−1 at 50 °C) for the decomposition of FA [24] Herein, one Co SAC catalyst was successfully obtained at relatively low temperature, where the boiling point of zinc was greatly reduced under vacuum condition [25], allowing zinc to evaporate at lower calcining temperature (as shown in the Scheme 1 ). This strategy offers a route for the preparation of high active Co SAC catalysts with tunable functionalized carbon structure, with high yield and low energy consumption. Importantly, the sublimated elements can be fully recovered and do not cause any environmental issues. Thus, vacuum calcination is a universal, cost saving, and environmentally friendly method for fabricating Metal-N-C materials. When applied to catalytic dehydrogenation of FA without any additives, the obtained Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the reaction with a high H2 production rate of 17,126 mLH2·gCo −1·h−1. At the same time, we found that the Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalysts can still exhibit astonished catalytic performance (with the H2 production rate of 19,540 mLH2·gCo −1·h−1) in 88% FA (cheapest commercially available grade of FA) due to its super stability and special mechanism of reaction. Until now, to the best of our knowledge, except a schiff based functionalized gold nanocatalyst [26], there has been no heterogeneous catalyst reported for the direct catalytic dehydrogenation of pure FA. Hence, the Co x -N-C(n)-Vacuo catalysts hold great potential in practical applications for their excellent catalytic performance in FA dehydrogenation. Moreover, the mechanism difference between nanoparticles (NP) and single-atom sites on aqueous formic acid dehydrogenation over coblat catalyst first elucidated by contrast experiment and isotope effect experiment. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Formic acid (FA) (88%), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), sodium formate (99%) and 1,10-phenanthroline (99%) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., LTD (China). The VULCAN XC-72R carbon black was bought from Cabot Corporation (US). All solvent (toluene, 1,4-dioxane, anhydrous ethanol) and other common reagents were of analytical grade. The deuterium reagents (DCO2H, HCO2D, DCO2D, DCO2Na, D2O) were purchased from J&K Chemicals. All commercial materials were used as received unless specified. The water was supplied by the molecular lab water purifier produced by Molecular Instrument Shanghai Co. LTD (China). 2.2 Preparation of the Co x -N-C(n)-Vacuo and Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 catalysts Take Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo as an example: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (64.8 mg, 0.22 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (517.2 mg, 1.74 mmol) (Zn:Co = 1:8, molar ratio) and 1,10-phenanthroline (693.0 mg, 3.85 mmol) (metal (include zinc and cobalt): phenanthroline = 1:2, molar ratio) were dissolved in ethanol (100 mL) under vigorous stirring for approximately 15 min at room temperature until a clear orange solution was obtained (the color changed to orange from pink after phenanthroline was added). The support Vulcan XC72R carbon (696 mg) was dispersed uniformly in the obtained solution through continuous stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. After the ethanol was removed by a rotatory evaporator, a black sample (1561 mg) was obtained. The sample was grinded into fine powders and transferred into a ceramic crucible, which was ready for calcination in the oven. The oven was evacuated to ca. 2000–4000 Pa by a circulating water vacuum pump (Shanghai Zhen Jie Experimental Equipment Co. LTD, China, SHB-III). And then the sample was calcinated under vacuum at 800 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. After heating the sample was cooled to room temperature with the oven. The obtained black powder was name as the Co x -N-C(n)-Vacuo catalyst (x is cobalt loading, wt%. n is calcining temperature,°C). The preparations of Co1.0-N-C(700)-Vacuo, Co1.0-N-C(750)-Vacuo and Co1.0-N-C(850)-Vacuo were the same as above except the calcining temperatures were 700, 750, and 850 °C, respectively. The preparation of Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 was the same as Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo except calcining under N2 flow with a rate of 0.1 L/min (before heating the tube was flushed with N2 for 1 h). The preparations of Co0.25-N-C(800)-Vacuo, Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo, Co1.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo, Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo, were the same as above except the amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O are proportionally adjusted. The preparations of Co0.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo (pure Zn sample) were prepared using the same method and the same amount of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (517.2 mg, 1.74 mmol) without Co(NO3)2·6H2O added. The catalysts with different Co/Zn molar ratio were prepared using the same method and the same amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (64.8 mg, 0.22 mmol) except adjusting the amount of Zn to make the Co/Zn molar ratio of 1:6, 1:10 and 1:0 (pure Co sample), respectively. 2.3 H2 generation from FA The hydrogen production from FA solution was performed in a 50 mL jacketed glass reactor. Before the reaction, FA (562 µL, 13 mmol) and solvent (1,4-dioxane, toluene or water, 10 mL) were added to the reactor, followed by being heated to the targeting temperature (100–130 °C) and let equilibrate for 60 min using the thermostat (high precision thermoregulation circulating oil bath, HUBER Technology Inc., Germany, KISS 208B). Then, the cobalt catalyst (50 mg) was added through an injector into the reaction vessel connected with the leveled manual burette, where the evolved gas volume was measured. After desired time, a certain amount of the evolved gas was taken for gas chromatography (GC) to identify and quantify its components. The reactions were repeatedly performed at least twice, showing differences less than 10%. The reaction in pure FA was operated with the same conditions as above except the FA (10 mL) was added without other solvent. For the recycling stability test, after the dehydrogenation of FA was completed, the catalyst was isolated from the reaction solution using centrifugation and washed with water, then dried in a vacuum at 80 °C for 6 h. The dried catalyst was used again in the catalytic dehydrogenation of the FA. 2.4 GC spectra The analysis of gas samples H2, CH4, CO and CO2, were performed on GC (Beijing Rayleigh Analytical Instrument co. LTD, China, SP-2000) with TDX-01 column connected to TCD (Thermal conductivity detector) or FID (Flame ionization detector) - Methanator. The detection limit for CO is 0.1 ppm. 2.5 Calculation methods The turnover frequency (TOF, h−1) reported here is a value based on the number of metal atoms in catalyst, which is calculated from the equation as follow: T O F = P a t m V g a s / R T 2 n m e t a l t Where, Patm is atmospheric pressure (101,325 Pa), Vgas is the final generated volume of H2 and CO2 gas, R is the universal gas constant (8.3145 m3·Pa·mol−1·K−1), T is the room temperature (298 K), nmetal is the mole number of the cobalt and t (h−1) is the reaction time (2 h). The H2 production rate (mL·g−1·h−1) reported here is a value based on the mass of cobalt in catalyst, which is calculated from the equation as follow: r H 2 = V g a s 2 m m e t a l t Where, Vgas is the final generated volume of H2 and CO2 gas, m metal is the mass of the cobalt in catalyst and t (h−1) is the reaction time (2 h). 2.6 Sample characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a JEOL model JEM-2011(HR) instrument. The atomic resolution images, high-angle annular dark field aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images and the elemental mapping of the catalysts were carried out on FEI Titan Themis G2 200 (S) S/TEM (US) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDS). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a PHI 1600 spectroscope. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas were determined from the N2 adsorption at 77 °C using V-Sorb 2800P (China). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded with a TD-3700 X-ray diffractometer (China). The metal content of the materials was analyzed by a T.J.A. ICP-9000 type inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) instrument. The X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (XAFS) (Co K-edge) were collected at BL14W beamline in Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). The storage rings of SSRF was operated at 3.5 GeV with a stable current of 200 mA. Using Si(111) double-crystal monochromator, the data collection were carried out in fluorescence mode using Lytle detector. All spectra were collected in ambient conditions. Data reduction, data analysis, and EXAFS fitting were performed according to the standard procedures using the ATHENA and ARTEMIS program intergrated within the Demeter packages. The energy calibration of the sample was conducted through a standard Co foil, which as a reference was simultaneously measured. For EXAFS modeling, The k3-weighted EXAFS spectra were obtained via subtracting the post-edge background from the overall absorption, normalization with respect to the edge-jump step, and Fourier transformation to real (R) space using a Hanning windows (dk = 1.0 Å) ranging from 2.0 to 11.0 Å−1. EXAFS of the Co foil is fitted and the obtained amplitude reduction factor S02 value (0.716) was set in the EXAFS analysis to determine the coordination numbers (CNs) in the Co-N scattering path in sample. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Charaterization of the catalysts The HRTEM image in Fig. 1 a and b reveal that the as-prepared Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst retains the initial spherical shape and size of the XC-72-R carbon black [27,28]. On these electron microscope images, no any individual metal nanoparticles with crystal structure were observed, combined with the ICP-AES results that Co 0.87 wt%, Zn 0.13 wt% (Table 1 ), indicating the metal particles with small size are highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst. Similar conclusions were also confirmed by the XRD results. As show in Fig. 2 a, the diffraction peaks of the metal (Zn or Co) were not found on the samples of Co1.0-N-C(750)-Vacuo, Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo or Co1.0-N-C(850)-Vacuo, indicating well dispersion of metals under these conditions. It should be noted, there is only small amount of zinc left in above samples, indicating that most of Zn has been removed during the vacuum calcining when the calcination temperature ≥ 750 °C. The HAADF-STEM images of the Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo was carried out as shown in Fig. 1c. It can be found that the Co and minim Zn atomically distributed on carbon substrate without any agglomerates. The elemental mapping (Fig. 1d) also indicates the homogeneous distribution of Co, Zn, N and O elements on the carbon support. Different from the vacuum conditions, there were metal nanoparticles in the Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 obviously, which was could be identified to ZnO by the lattice (0.27 nm) (Fig. 1e) and the crystal plane diffraction peaks (Fig. 2a). Moreover we can find the XC-72 carbon nanospheres are wrapped by small fragmented zinc oxide particles (Fig. 1e), which can increase the number of micropores and block the active sites of the material. The same result can be found in sample Co1.0-N-C(700)-Vacuo, indicates that zinc could not be removed under vacuum when the temperature is 700 °C or under N2 flow when the temperature is even higher as 800 °C. As mentioned above, the purpose of adding zinc is to isolate the cobalt atoms, as it can be vaporized during the high-temperature calcining. The boiling point of zinc is 907 °C at atmospheric pressure, so the sample must be calcined at least above 950 °C to remove Zn [17]. Because the vapor tension of zinc is 3728 Pa when the temperature is 650 °C [29]. And the circulating water vacuum pump which can provide the ultimate vacuum with 2000–4000 Pa. So, the lowest temperature at which zinc can vaporize is approximately 650 °C theoretically. In fact, zinc can be removed when the temperature ≥ 750 °C under our vacuum experimental conditions. To further characterize the existence state of C, N, Co in the Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst, XPS investigations were performed. As shown in Fig. 2b, the larger peak at 284.5 eV was attributed to carbon bonded to carbon, and the peak at 285.7 eV was attributed to the carbon atoms which were bonded to nitrogen atoms [30,31]. The peak around 289.9 eV was attributed to the carbon atoms on Co-N-C bonding [30,31]. In Fig. 2c, the main contribution observed in the N 1s spectra of Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo hint at pyridinic-N (binding energy around 398.5 eV) and a combination of graphitic and pyrrolic-N species (around 400.8 eV). The peak at 399.5 eV was attributed to the nitrogen atoms combined in Co-N [32]. In Fig. 2d, the Co 2p region, the two peaks with binding energy centered at 780.3 and 795.9 eV along with weak satellite peaks at around 785.0 and 800.6 eV are attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively (indicates that Co has an oxidation state between 0 and +2). When compared with the reduced Co sample (778.3 and 793.3 eV) [33,34], an energy shift of over 2.0 and 2.6 eV were detected, as observed previously for N-metal interactions, indicating that the cobalt may exist in the form of N-Co [12]. There were a weak peak at 1021.7 eV in Fig. 2e and a peak at 532.0 eV in Fig. 2f, which attributed to the Zn atoms on N-Zn bonding and O atoms on C-O bonding [35,36], indicating that the zinc exist in the form of N-Zn and oxygen exist in the form of C-O. In addition, the adsorption experimental results were shown in Fig. 3 , that all samples (included Co1.0-N-C(n)-Vacuo and Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2) displayed similar pore structure which was also as similar as XC-72-R carbon black [28,29]. We can find that the sample Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 has bigger surface area than Co1.0-N-C(n)-Vacuo, this is due to the presence of more microporous in Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 which is caused by zinc oxide nanoparticles (Fig. 1e). By comparing the XRD patterns of catalysts with different cobalt loading (Fig. 4 a), we can find that all metal particles are highly dispersed on the catalysts, except for the diffraction peaks of Co0 appeared in sample of Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo. This indicated that the Co nanoparticles can be formed when the mass fraction of cobalt reached 2%. We can infer the same conclusion by HRTEM image of Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo in Fig. 4f. There are Co nanoparticles around 20 nm in diameter embedded in the carbon, which can be proved by lattice spacing in Fig. 4f. Furthermore, the local coordination environment of Co atoms and chemical states of Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo were characterized by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). As shown in Fig. 4b, The absorption edge energy at 7728.3 eV in the XANES spectrum of Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo suggesting that Co2+ is the dominating Co species [12]. As shown in Fig. 4c, the peak at 1.35 Å in Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo is attributed to the most typical Co-N bonds [18]. According to fitting result (Fig. 4d), the Co-N coordination numbers in SAC sample is 4. In general, combined with the TEM, HAADF-STEM, XPS and EXAFS characterization, the Co states in Co x -N-C(800)-Vacuo catalysts were dispersed as single-atom sites (labeled as Co(II)N4) when the cobalt load (x) ≤ 1.0% wt. Whereas, when the cobalt load ≥ 2.0% wt, samples will contain Co nanoparticles. 3.2 Catalytic properties In the experiments of hydrogen production from FA catalyzed by Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst. Various of the reaction conditions were investigated, as shown in Table 2 entries 1–4, demonstrating the optimal temperature is 120 °C, and the best reaction solvent is a green solvent - water (Table 2 entry 5). Under the optimal reaction conditions, H2 production rate can reach 17,126 mL·g−1·h−1. Moreover, what is even more exciting is that the obtained Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalysts can be successfully used in pure FA system (Table 2 entry 7) with very high catalytic activity (with H2 production rate 19,540 mL·g−1·h−1). It's worth noting that high concentration of FA mean high hydrogen storage. However, currently, the FA concentrations used are mainly in the range of 0.2–10 mol·L−1 in the reported work, which are not high enough for practical application [26]. The carbonization temperature is one of the critical parameters that determine the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 5 a, at vacuum, 700, 750, 800, 850 °C were tested, demonstrating the optimal temperature of 800 °C. The lowest hydrogen production rate was found at 700 °C vacuum condition, which may be results of the existence of unremoved zinc in the form of zinc oxide, where the active sites were embedded. When the calcining temperature rise to 750, 800 and 850 °C, all the zinc can be removed. The one reason for the excellent catalytic performance of the sample calcinated at 800 °C (Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo) may be the high specific surface area (Fig. 3b). In addition, at the same temperature of 800 °C, higher specific surface area can be obtained under nitrogen than vacuum (Fig. 3d), but the hydrogen production rate of Co1.0-N-C(800)-N2 was lower than Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo (Table 2 entry 8), which indicates that vacuum condition is more effective for the removal of zinc to make high exposure of the active sites and improvement of the catalytic activity than nitrogen at 800 °C. A series of catalysts with different Co/Zn ratios were prepared and studied in more details in the FA dehydrogenation (Fig. 5b). The best Co/Zn ratio is turned to be 1:8. It is clear that the H2 production rate of the sample without zinc added was only 2941 mL·g−1·h−1, which proved the necessity of the addition of zinc. As mentioned above, the zinc was served as ‘fence’ to expand the adjacent distances between Co atoms. But after calcination there is a small amount of zinc left in the material in the form of N-Zn (Fig. 2e, Table 1). In order to confirm the effect of residual zinc on the reaction, we took Co0.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo and Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo as the samples of comparative tests. According to ICP results (Table 1), these two samples have the similar zinc content, the difference is that Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo has cobalt and Co0.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo does not. And as shown in Fig. 5c, the H2 production rate based on a gram of catalyst for Co0.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo was only 13.47 mL·g−1·h−1, which was significantly lower than Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst (149.00 mL·g−1·h−1). This indicates that zinc has very low catalytic performance for hydrogen production from formic acid. Moreover, no indication of Co-Zn interaction was indicated by the the fitting for EXAFS results (Fig. 4d), indicate that a significant Zn effect on activity can be neglected. The same conclusion was also found in Ref. [13]. The results of catalysts with different Co loading (Table 2 entries 5 and 9–12) show that the TOF values and H2 production rate increases as the Co loading decreases. When the mass fraction of cobalt reached 0.5%, the H2 production rate was up to 27,361 mL·g−1·h−1 and 144.77 mL·g−1·h−1 based on a gram of catalyst. The H2 production rate varies little as the Co load decreases to 0.25%, so the Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo was considered to be the optimal sample. A low hydrogen production rate can be observed on the Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst, which was confirmed that Co nanoparticles (NP) were formed in it, indicating Co NP has low catalytic performance for formic acid [13]. The KSCN was added to the reaction systems on both Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo and Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo to poison Co single active sites via strong interactions between SCN− and Co single active sites [12]. The catalytic activity of Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo was decreased signifificantly but Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo was decreased little (Table 2 entries 13 and 14). This phenomenon indicate that the atomically dispersed active sites in the catalysts caused by strong cobalt-nitrogen coordination is believed to be the key to the success of this reaction. Another thing to add is that the poisonous effect of KSCN is not really that comprehensive, as reported by Cheng et al [37]. So, there is some catalytic activity on Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo with KSCN added (Table 2 entry 13). In addition, as shown in Fig. 6 , the hydrogen production along with the reaction time of Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo and Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo at optimal conditions were provided. We can confirm that the FA is almost completely converted to H2 and CO2 with trace amounts of CO (3.956 ppm, Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo) by gas chromatography with a methane reformer. However, although the selectivity of FA decomposition is > 99%, the conversion rate of the reaction in 2 h (the reaction time we take) is only 4.52%. Except for the FA conversion rate is 0.28% reacted in high concentration of formic acid, the FA conversion rates under different catalysts and reaction conditions were between 1.06 and 4.65% and positively correlated with H2 production rate based on a gram of catalyst (Table 2). The reuse of Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo catalyst was also carried out under the condition of 120 °C in the water. After the first using, washing and drying, the catalyst showed certain deactivation, with H2 production rate deduction of about 3000 mL·g−1·h−1. But the catalytic properties can be kept basically constant in the following reuse process (Fig. 5d). Combined with the experimental fact that the catalyst can be used in high concentration formic acid, these suggest that the catalyst has high stability. 3.3 Comparison of reaction path between Co single atoms and nanoparticles catalysts As mentioned above, the single atom catalysts (SAC) Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo can still exhibit high catalytic performance in 88% FA. Until now, almost all formic acid decomposition reactions take place in low concentration formic acid solutions (0.2–10 mol·L−1). For catalytic dehydrogenation of formic acid, it is generally recognized that the whole reaction progress starts from deprotonation, and then the formed HCO2 − further dehydrogenates to generate CO2 followed by producing H2 molecule (i. e. HCO2 − dehydrogenation, path I) [8]. Considering that HCO2 − is main reactant of path I, so the value of c(HCO2 −)/c(HCO2H) should have a significant impact on the activity. From the Dissociation Formula, we can easily calculate c(HCO2 −)/c(HCO2H) was 3.0% and 0.28% respectively, when the initial concentration of formic acid was 0.2 M and 23.5 M (88%. wt). 3.0% is ten times as much as 0.28%, this may be why dehydrogenation is difficult in high concentration formic acid. But our SAC can have a high catalytic performance in 88% FA. It got us thinking, whether the reaction mechanism on the SAC is different from that of the current catalysts. As a new type of catalyst, the SAC bridge the gap between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [38], due to there is similar coordination environments between SAC and homogeneous catalysts, etc. Inspired by an report on the mechanism of the dehydrogenation of formic acid catalyzed by homogeneous cobalt catalysts [39]. The reaction mechanism on the SAC may be proceed as the HCO2H dehydrogenation (path II), which HCO2H is adsorbed on SAC and decomposed into HCO2 − and H+ that are adsorbed on Co2+ and N, respectively. The adsorbed HCO2 − generates CO2 and another hydrogen adsorbed on Co2+, followed by the combinative desorption of hydrogen atoms to product H2. The key difference between the path I and II is that there is H+ desorped from catalyst in path I, but none in path II. So, if the reaction is going to follow path I, the reaction must be affected by the concentration of H+ and HCO2 −, path II is not. As shown in Table 2 entries 15 and 16, sodium formate (four times the equivalent of FA) was added in the reaction system, we found the H2 production rate increased 44% on Co2.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo which has been identified as a NP catalyst. But when the Co0.5-N-C(800)-Vacuo (SAC) was used, the presence of HCO2Na did not significantly alter the gas formation. Thereby may proving that the reaction is going to follow path I on Co nanoparticles (NP) catalyst, and path II on Co SAC. To elucidate the plausible reaction pathways by which the dehydrogenation take place over NP catalyst and SAC, isotopic labeling studies are performed. As shown in Table 3 , entries 1–10 are on NP catalyst and entries 11–20 are on SAC. In order to exclude the influence of Co single-atom active sites on the NP catalyst, the KSCN was added to the reaction systems to poison them. We can see by comparing entry 1 (11) and 6 (16), 1 (11) and 8 (18), 4 (14) and 7 (17), 4 (14) and 9 (19), 5(15) and 10(20), under the same conditions once HCO2Na or DCO2Na was added, the dehydrogenation of formic acid can be significantly promoted on NP catalyst, but no significant variation on SAC. These confirms the above conclusion that the reaction proceeds through the HCO2 − dehydrogenation (path I) on NP catalyst and HCO2H dehydrogenation (path II) on SAC. In the system with formates, by comparing numbers entry 6 (16) and 8 (18), 7 (17) and 9 (19), when HCO2Na was replaced with DCO2Na, we can observe that the isotope effect significantly on NP catalyst but not on SAC. And then, by comparing numbers entry 6 (16) and 7 (17), 8 (18) and 9 (19), when HCO2H was replaced with DCO2D, we can observe that the isotope effect on SAC significantly but not on NP catalyst. These results indicated that HCO2Na is a key reactant to reaction on NP catalyst, and HCOOH on SAC. Thereby confirm that the two catalysts have different reaction path, and the reaction on SAC through the path II rather than path I, NP catalyst is the opposite. In the system without formates, the value of KIE, entry 4 > 2 > 3 (NP catalyst) and entry 14 > 12 > 13 (SAC), indicating that C-H bond cleavage is the slow reaction step no matter what path the reaction is followed. Moreover, as shown in Table 3 entry 5(15) and 10(20), when H2O was replaced to D2O, the reaction rate was deteriorated on SAC, but not on NP catalyst. This indicated that the water was involved in the reaction on SAC. There is a single-atom Co-dispersed nitrogen-doped carbon (Co-NC) catalyst which is similar to our SAC was reported by Deng et al. [40]. They found that H2 can be heterolytically dissociated over the frustrated Lewis acid-base Co-N pair to Hδ−-Co-N-Hδ+ and then transformed into the Brønsted acid-base OHδ−-Co-N-Hδ+ pair accompanied by H2 regeneration via an H2O-mediated path. In order to verify the H2-catalyzed acid transformation, the acid type of SAC was measured by situ IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR). In Py-IR detected at 150 °C show that the Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo shows high Lewis acid peak at 1450 cm−1 and a very low Brønsted acid peak at 1540 cm−1, which results from the positive Co2+ of the Co1.0-N-C(800)-Vacuo surface (Fig. 7 ). After HCO2H-H2O activation, the Lewis acid content decreased from 0.06611 to 0.01890 mmol/g, accompanied by the Brønsted acid increased from 0.00572 to 0.01223 mmol/g (increased 2.14 times). Moreover, the signal detected at 250 °C ascribed to strong acidity indicates a more obvious increase in the Brønsted acid from 0.00270 to 0.00778 mmol/g (increased 2.88 times), which is mainly due to the strong acidity of the Brønsted acidity. The decrease of Lewis acid and the increase of Brønsted acid especially strong Brønsted acid, may be shown indirectly that the frustrated Lewis acid-base pair (Co-N) transformed into a Brønsted acid-base pair (OHδ−-Co-N-Hδ+) on the surface under the mediation of HCO2H-H2O. Similar materials and conclusions can also be proved in Tsang's research (Ref. [40]). Referring to this process, the possible dehydrogenationof FA mechanism on SAC has been proposed as shown in Scheme 2 . Firstly, complex 2 is formed by coordination between HCO2H molecule and Co(II)N4 active site (1) on SAC. And the second step is O-H and C-H of HCO2H activation resulting in CO2 release and the formation of acid-base pair 3. Then the reaction step could be the formic acid assisted H2 formation and the regenerating of complex 2 (route a). And the acid-base pair 3 can also be transformed into the Brønsted acid-base OHδ−-Co-N-Hδ+ pair 4 with H2 emitted by H2O assisted (route b). Finally, 4 can be dehydrated and regenerated to complex 2 by the action of formic acid. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a low-temperature strategy for SAC with high yield and low energy consumption by vacuum calcining. The obtained SAC could make high exposure of the active sites and improvement of the catalytic activity. When the obtained SAC catalyst was used in the FA dehydrogenation reactions, ultrahigh catalytic activity was observed. Moreover, the catalyst maintained catalytic activity even in the high concentration FA. In order to explain the special reaction phenomenon found on the SAC catalyst, for example, can be used in high concentration FA, the auxiliary reagent sodium formate did not promote the reaction, etc. The mechanism of SAC and NP catalyst were both discussed through contrast experiment and isotope effect experiment. Finally confirmed the reaction proceeds through the HCO2 − dehydrogenation path on NP catalyst and HCO2H dehydrogenation path on SAC. These findings can solve the problems of existing catalysts for hydrogen production from FA and are believed to have profound effects in this field (Table 4 ). coredata.dc:description: Various Co-N-C catalysts including nanoparticles and single-atom sites were prepared using a low-temperature synthetic strategy by vacuum calcining with high exposure of the active sites and low energy consumption. When used in the formic acid (FA) dehydrogenation reaction, the obtained single-atom sites catalyst displayed high catalytic activity with a high H2 production rate of 27,361 mL·g−1·h−1. Moreover, the single-atom sites catalysts can still exhibit astonished catalytic performance in 88% FA (cheapest commercially available grade of FA) due to their super stability and special mechanism of reaction. From TEM, XRD, HAADF-STEM, XPS, and XANES characterization, the atomically dispersed active sites in the single-atom sites catalysts caused by strong metal-nitrogen coordination is believed to be the key to the success of this reaction. Moreover, the mechanism difference between nanoparticles and single-atom sites on aqueous formic acid dehydrogenation over coblat catalyst was illustrated.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism difference between nanoparticles and single-atom sites on aqueous formic acid dehydrogenation over coblat catalyst
